title: Fishermen discover the giant shell of an extinct glyptodon which lived 10,000 years ago in Argentina
text:
When a group of Argentinian fishermen settled on the banks of the Alegre creek on Monday, the last creature they expected to be among their haul was a 10,000-year-old glyptodon.

But wedged into the sands of Barrio La Flecha in Ezeiza, Greater Buenos Aires, was hidden a shell of the extinct armadillo-like animal which roamed South America during the pre-Ice Age.

Imanol Ojeda stumbled upon the curious hard object and, after scraping off the dirt with his knife, discovered it was a shell.

Wedged into the sands of Barrio La Flecha in Ezeiza, Greater Buenos Aires, was hidden a shell of a 10,000-year-old glyptodon which roamed South America pre-Ice Age

Fishermen Imanol Ojeda (third from left) stumbled upon the curious hard object and, after scraping off the dirt with his knife, discovered it was a shell

Oscar Vique, from the Marcos Paz Paleontologican Reserve, said that the tough shell remained 98 per cent intact and hailed it a 'very well-preserved specimen'.

And one of the fishermen, Rodolfo Cuenca, said that the historical find made him proud to be from Ezeiza.

This is the second time the remnants of a glyptodon – a species of glyptodont – have been found in the area after farmer Jose Antonio Nievas saw what he believed to be a dinosaur egg in the mud in 2015.

At the time of this discovery, Dr Ross MacPhee, a curator in the American Museum of Natural History's Department of Mammalogy told MailOnline that complete shells are very rare, making Monday's find even more remarkable.

And Professor Adrian Lister of the Natural History Museum in London explained it is common to find fossils buried in the bank of streams and rivers, because flowing water gradually erodes the bank to expose ancient shells and bones.

Glyptodons are believed to be giant creatures which were wiped out in the Ice Age some 10,000 years ago.
